text:
When I read "tools for everyone", I think about the opposite of "tools only usable by experts". I don't mean that everybody should use the tools, but everyone that wants/needs to, can use them. And I neither mean that experts must not use these tools.

Maybe a good example is Max/MSP. Some musicians with no programming skills can use it and begin to program, experts can also find it usefull, especially for the audio processing part of the tool. As an "expert" programmer, I prefer setting audio flows with MaxMSP than JavaScript/WebAudio (or even Faust, which is  a text language designed for audio processing). I just find that for programmers it is sometime frustrating and more complicated than text language. That's why I believe in mixed tools: both visual and text languages.

text: <@UFLN9JFRT>  the source is available on <https://git.s-ol.nu/mmm;|https://git.s-ol.nu/mmm;> the website you are viewing the article on is also running the system itself. There is also a sandbox Version with editing enabled at <https://ba.s-ol.nu|https://ba.s-ol.nu> (but it doesn't support server-side code execution for security reasons)

attachments.title: MMM: lunar low-gravity scripting playground
attachments.text: mmm is not the www, because it runs on MoonScript.

text: <@UEQ6M68H0> I think Python rode the wave of the web (and recently the data science and ml boom). To displace one of those 3 languages you mention, I think you'd have to find a big wave to ride and/or have something really simple yet radical. I like what you said here: "I feel the battle is one to supplant both Excel and the top 3 languages, in one tool that finally bridges these two almost uncommunicating realms.". I think of Excel as a 2D language, and have been trying to bridge the world of the 1-D => AST languages with grid languages like Excel. I also think someone could make some wholly novel type of 3-D language in AR or VR that could be a hit

text: <@UMVFWPZ36> It’s interesting that spreadsheets and Hypercard are both effectively views into tables (with Hypercard providing custom row editors). I share your intuition that the future will be in the direction of more general structures, but I’d bet on graphs over tensors.

elements.text: It’s interesting that spreadsheets and Hypercard are both effectively views into tables (with Hypercard providing custom row editors). I share your intuition that the future will be in the direction of more general structures, but I’d bet on graphs over tensors.

text: <@ULM3U6275> what about graphs of tensors? I like what Apple Numbers has done recently, where they've created floating grids. A slightly different take on the UI of a spreadsheet that I think is in an interesting direction.

elements.text: what about graphs of tensors? I like what Apple Numbers has done recently, where they've created floating grids. A slightly different take on the UI of a spreadsheet that I think is in an interesting direction.
Section 2.1 is wonderfully well-written

text:
On a slight tangent, what is *up* with your website? Why does <https://s-ol.nu/ba> redirect to <https://ba.s-ol.nu/articles/mmmfs/:%20text/html+interactive>? Is it a permalink guaranteed to continue to redirect there over time, or is it like the index page of a blog? Can I rely on <https://ba.s-ol.nu/articles/mmmfs> working over time?

Why does clicking on the link lead to a blank page for several seconds before the content pops up? Are you converting from pdf on demand or something?!

Is there somewhere I can read about the facet dropdown and so on?

text: To my knowledge Java is still a very commonly used server-side language. Python became embedded into Linux a long time ago in multiple subsystems; various build systems like yum which is the essential tool used in Centos/RedHat, and so on. In fact Centos 6.5 and earlier requires Python 2.6 else you can't run the OS, and for some reason if you install python 3 which has breaking changes to 2.6, Centos malfunctions. Most linux distributions are collections of hundreds of different utilities, and each of those has a dependency chain. The poor design of the Unix shared library (DLL's to those familiar with Windows) has been its achilles heel for a long time. This is why linux doesn't make much forward progress; most of the builds are just reshufflings of the existing tools rather than forward motion, held back by the inability to gracefully move forward. The whole Docker ecosystem can be considered to exist solely to fix the shared library conflict issue, by creating a custom environment for each program to exist in. A terrible band-aid over a festering sore IMHO.

elements.text: To my knowledge Java is still a very commonly used server-side language. Python became embedded into Linux a long time ago in multiple subsystems; various build systems like yum which is the essential tool used in Centos/RedHat, and so on. In fact Centos 6.5 and earlier requires Python 2.6 else you can't run the OS, and for some reason if you install python 3 which has breaking changes to 2.6, Centos malfunctions. Most linux distributions are collections of hundreds of different utilities, and each of those has a dependency chain. The poor design of the Unix shared library (DLL's to those familiar with Windows) has been its achilles heel for a long time. This is why linux doesn't make much forward progress; most of the builds are just reshufflings of the existing tools rather than forward motion, held back by the inability to gracefully move forward. The whole Docker ecosystem can be considered to exist solely to fix the shared library conflict issue, by creating a custom environment for each program to exist in. A terrible band-aid over a festering sore IMHO.
